RSO (AR)

Legal Issues with Air Rifles

Canadian law controls the use of rifles through the Firearms Act and the Criminal Code.

 

Firearms Act

An air rifle with a muzzle velocity of 152.4 metres per second (mps) or more is considered a firearm under the Firearms Act. The Cadet air rifle has a muzzle velocity of 150 mps, so it is exempt from the specific safe storage, transportation and handling requirements set out in the regulations supporting the Firearms Act.

 

Criminal Code

Recent court decisions have determined that an air rifle capable of causing serious bodily injury or death (i.e. with a muzzle velocity of 65 mps or more) can be considered a firearm under the Criminal Code of Canada. The Criminal Code requires that reasonable precautions be taken to use, carry, handle, store, transport and ship firearms in a safe and secure manner.

NOTE: there may also be Provincial and Municipal regulations for air rifles that affect their use locally.

 

Click here to read a RCMP fact sheet on air rifles.
